Handcrafted CSS

I'm going to review a few of the best practices and new CSS I learned from reading Handcrafted CSS: More Bulletproof Web Design by Dan Cederholm.

Note: This is not meant to be walkthrough!

Assignment: Work with floats to create a coffee menu with optimal markup. Keep usability in mind.

Example 1

Dan recommended making the entire row clickable including link titles and prices. Why you ask?

Fitts's law: is a model of human movement primarily used in humanâ€“computer interaction and ergonomics that predicts that the time required to rapidly move to a target area is a function of the distance to the target and the size of the target.

So by increasing the clickable area, this will help increase usability and make for a better user experience. Sounds awesome!

I'm already familiar with display: block but I will need to clear my floats when using block-level elements within containers.

overflow: hidden: a method of self-clearing any floats that occur within the container element.

Here is the CSS I added to my list item's a tag:

ul.lst li a { display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 2%; }
  • Latte 2.79
  • Cappuccino 2.99
  • Espresso 2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) 10.49

Looks ok, but the usability is still bad. Currently, I have no hover state to tell the user which item they are selecting. A divider to visually separate the items is needed too.

Example 2

So now I need to make improvements by adding a bottom border and a hover state to my CSS:

ul.lst li a { border-bottom: 1px solid #ddd; display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 2%; } ul.lst li:hover { background: #fff8dc; }
  • Latte 2.79
  • Cappuccino 2.99
  • Espresso 2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) 10.49

Move your mouse over the different items. Almost perfect, but there are still two issues. Notice the double border at the very bottom? I also want add a soft background color to every other row to improve readability.

:nth-of-type(n)

Setting a background on every other menu item will really help each item stand out. With the :nth-of-type(n) selector, I can easily achieve this:

The :nth-of-type(n) selector matches every element that is the nth child, of a particular type, of its parent. N can be a number, a keyword, or a formula.

Luckily, there are some keywords I can use to help match child elements:

p:nth-of-type(even)
p:nth-of-type(odd)
Odd and even are keywords that can be used to match child elements whose index is odd or even (the index of the first child is 1).

Now I can set the background color for every other row:

ul.lst li:nth-of-type(even) { background: #F6F4F0; }

Next, I need to remove the bottom border on the fourth row to avoid double borders. I used this formula:

(an + b).
A represents a cycle size, n is a counter (starts at 0), and b is an offset value.

Here is what the CSS looks like:

ul.lst li:nth-of-type(4n+0) { border-bottom: 0; }

Example 3: Final results

  • Latte 2.79
  • Cappuccino 2.99
  • Espresso 2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) 10.49

Perfect! By making a few simple changes, I really improved usability overall. I love this stuff!
